name: Abnormal Parent / Child Process
description: A process that typically launches a small, consistent number of child processes has launched a new child process. Investigate the new child process or the parent process to see if it is benign.

name: Account Created and Deleted in Short Timeframe
description: Detects when an account was created and deleted in a short period of time.

name: Account Creation Anomaly
description: An anomalously large number of accounts were created in a 5-minute interval or a user created an account for the first time in at least 14 days. Check the originating account and the new accounts for malicious behavior.

name: Account Disabled or Blocked for Sign in Attempts
description: Detects when an account is disabled or blocked for sign in but tried to log in

name: Account Lockout
description: Identifies user account which has been locked because the user tried to sign in too many times with an incorrect user ID or password.

name: Account Login Failure Anomaly
description: An anomalously large number of login failures from an internal source IP address to an internal destination IP address was observed for an account.

name: Acronis Cyber Protect Cloud - Detections
description: An Acronis Cyber Protect Cloud alert was detected.

name: AMSI Disabled via Registry Modification
description: Detects changes to the Windows registry that disable the Antimalware Scan Interface (AMSI) by setting the AmsiEnable value to 0. Threat actors commonly use this technique to impair security defenses and evade detection. Disabling AMSI allows malicious payloads to execute without interference, significantly increasing the risk of system compromise, privilege escalation, and data exfiltration.

name: Anydesk Remote Access Software Service Installation
description: Detects the installation of the anydesk software service. Which could be an indication of anydesk abuse if you the software isn't already used.

name: APDS XSS Redirection
description: Detects the creation of malicious Microsoft Management Console (MMC) files crafted to exploit a known XSS vulnerability in the apds.dll library for arbitrary code execution. Adversaries can abuse this vulnerability by embedding malicious script within specially crafted MMC files. When a user opens such a file, the script executes within the context of the user's session, potentially allowing for arbitrary code execution. This can lead to various malicious activities, including privilege escalation, installation of malware, data exfiltration, and further compromise of the affected system. By leveraging the trusted nature of MMC files, adversaries can trick users into executing malicious code without raising immediate suspicion.

name: Application Usage Anomaly
description: An internal user who usually runs a few applications with internal service IP addresses suddenly runs a new application. Investigate the application to see if it is benign. Check with the user to see if this was expected.

name: AWS - Malicious Host Access
description: AWS activity was detected from a source with a negative reputation.

name: AWS - Root logon detected
description: A successful AWS login for the root user was detected.

name: AWS Access Key Created
description: An AWS API key was created for a user.

name: AWS AMI Made Public
description: An AWS AMI was made public. Check with the user to make sure this was intentional.

name: AWS CloudTrail Important Change
description: An AWS trail was disabled, deleted, or changed.

name: AWS Config Disabling Channel/Recorder
description: An AWS config service was disabled.

name: AWS Console Successful Logins Outside the US
description: A successful login outside the US was detected for the following AWS user.

name: AWS GuardDuty - Detections
description: Stellar Cyber detected a suspicious alert originally reported by AWS GuardDuty.

name: AWS IAM S3Browser User or AccessKey Creation
description: The S3 browser utility was detected creating IAM User or an AccessKey.

name: AWS Identity Center Identity Provider Change
description: A change in the AWS Identity Center identity provider was detected.

name: AWS Logging Stopped
description: AWS CloudTrail logging was stopped. Check with the user to make sure this was intentional.

name: AWS Not MFA Authenticated
description: A successful AWS login occurred without MFA verification.

name: AWS S3 Ransomware
description: Possible AWS S3 ransomware was observed. Check with the user.

name: AWS SecurityHub Findings Evasion
description: SecurityHub findings were modified.

name: Azure - Custom Script Extension Added to a Virtual Machine
description: This rule detects the creation or modification of a virtual machine extension in Microsoft Azure. Adversaries may utilize this technique to execute arbitrary commands on virtual machines.

name: Azure - Diagnostic Settings Deleted
description: This rule detects the deletion of diagnostic settings in Microsoft Azure. Diagnostic settings are often used to forward critical logs used for infrastructure and security monitoring. An adversary may delete diagnostic settings to bypass detection mechanisms that rely on these logs.

name: Azure - Event Hub Deleted
description: This rule detects the deletion of Event Hubs in Microsoft Azure. Event Hubs are responsible for forwarding logs to detection platforms like SIEMs. Adversaries may disable log forwarding through this technique to avoid detection when performing activities in a compromised environment

name: Azure - Event Hub Namespace Deleted
description: This rule detects the deletion of Event Hub Namespaces in Microsoft Azure. Event Hub Namespaces can contain one or more Event Hubs, which are responsible for forwarding logs to detection platforms like SIEMs. Adversaries may disable log forwarding through this technique to avoid detection when performing activities in a compromised environment.

name: Azure - Identity Eligible for Owner Role in IAM
description: This rule detects when the Azure Owner role is made as an eligible assignment within Microsoft's Privileged Identity Management (PIM) product. The Azure Owner role grants full access to manage all resources in an Azure subscription, making it a high-risk, high-privilege role that should be carefully controlled. Adversaries may seek to obtain this role to gain unrestricted access to Azure resources, potentially leading to data theft, service disruption, or further privilege escalation across the entire Azure environment. Monitoring such assignments is crucial for maintaining a strong security posture and preventing potential misuse of privileged access.

name: Azure - Identity Eligible for User Access Administrator Role in IAM
description: This rule detects when an identity becomes eligible for the User Access Administrator role in Azure IAM. The User Access Administrator role is a privileged role that can be used to escalate privileges to other roles, including the Owner role. This detection is crucial for identifying potential privilege escalation attempts or unauthorized changes to IAM permissions.

name: Azure - IP Address IOC Match
description: This rule identifies when a user attempts to access Microsoft Azure resources from an IP address associated with Crowdstrike's threat intelligence feed. This indicates a malicious actor has gained access to the Azure environment and is performing reconnaissance against it (it should be noted that IP addresses that were known to have hosted malicious activity in the past might not necessarily do so in the present).

name: Azure - Managed Identity Federated Credentials Created
description: This rule identifies when federated credentials are added to a user managed identity. This behavior could indicate that an attacker has a foothold in the environment and is attempting to establish persistence through a managed identity, with federated credentials to an external identity provider under their control.

name: Azure - Network Security Group Modified to Allow Ingress from Public Internet
description: This rule detects the modification of network security group in Microsoft Azure to allow ingress traffic from public internet. Adversaries may utilize this technique to gain unrestricted access to the network.

name: Azure - New Owner Role Assignment
description: This rule detects when an Owner role is successfully assigned within Azure Active Directory. Owner roles grant full access to manage all resources, including the ability to assign roles to other users, making this one of the most privileged roles in Azure. The detection specifically monitors for the successful completion of role assignments by correlating the initial assignment request with subsequent confirmation logs. This activity could indicate privilege escalation attempts or account takeover when performed by unexpected entities or during suspicious time windows.

name: Azure - Self-Assignment of Owner Role
description: This rule detects the self-assignment of owner role by a user. Adversaries may leverage this technique to achieve persistence and privilege escalation.

name: Azure - Successful Login Outside the US
description: A successful login outside the US was detected for the following Azure user.

name: Azure AD Apps Modified To Allow Multi-Tenant Access
description: Microsoft Entra ID (formerly Azure Active Directory) observed an application being modified to allow multi-tenant access. Check with the organization to be sure this was expected.

name: Azure AD Custom Domains Changed
description: Microsoft Entra ID (formerly Azure Active Directory) observed a custom domain being changed. Check with the organization to be sure this was expected.

name: Azure AD Risk Detection
description: Azure AD reported risky sign in activity from the indicated user.

name: Azure AD Sign in from AzureHound
description: A user logged in utilizing a user agent associated with the known hack tool Azure Hound.

name: Azure Application Gateway Changed
description: The Azure Application Gateway Changed rules are used to identify events when an Azure application's gateway is changed. Any one or more of these will trigger the Azure Application Gateway Changed alert type.

name: Azure DNS Zone Changed
description: The Azure DNS Zone Changed rules are used to identify events when an Azure DNS zone is changed. Any one or more of these will trigger the Azure DNS Zone Changed alert type.

name: Azure New CloudShell Created
description: The Azure New CloudShell Created rules are used to identify events when an Azure new Cloud Shell is changed. Any one or more of these will trigger the Azure New CloudShell Created alert type.

name: Azure Security Configuration Changed
description: The Azure Security Configuration Changed rules are used to identify events when an Azure security configuration is changed. Any one or more of these will trigger the Azure Security Configuration Changed alert type.

name: Azure User Added to Global Admin Group
description: An Azure user was added to the Global Admin group in your environment.

name: AzureAdRisk - Detections
description: Stellar Cyber detected a suspicious alert originally reported by Microsoft Entra RiskDetection.

name: Backup Catalogs Deleted by Ransomware
description: The wbadmin.exe utility was used to delete the backup catalog. Ransomware and other malware do this to prevent system recovery. Check with the user.

name: Bad Destination Reputation Anomaly
description: A destination IP address with a bad reputation has received an anomalously large number of connections. Investigate the connections and consider blocking the destination IP address.

name: Bad Reputation Login
description: A successful login was observed from an IP address with a history of malicious activity. Check with the user.

name: Bad Source Reputation Anomaly
description: A source IP address with a bad reputation has made an anomalously large number of connections. Investigate the connections and consider blocking the source IP address.

name: Base64 Decode and Execute Memory Dump Python Script
description: Detects the use of base64 decoding followed by the execution of a Python script designed to perform memory dumping operations. Such scripts may be used to extract sensitive information, including secrets and credentials, from the memory of CI/CD pipeline runners. This behavior is indicative of potential supply chain compromises or unauthorized analysis attempts. Monitoring for such activities is crucial to detect security threats and prevent unauthorized access to sensitive data.

name: Bitdefender IP - Detections
description: Stellar Cyber detected a suspicious alert originally reported by Bitdefender.

name: Bitdefender Threat - Detections
description: Stellar Cyber detected a suspicious alert originally reported by Bitdefender.

name: Bitdefender URL - Detections
description: Stellar Cyber detected a suspicious alert originally reported by Bitdefender.

name: Bitlocker Key Retrieval
description: Monitor and alert for Bitlocker key retrieval.

name: Bitrat Activity
description: Activity related to Bitrat a remote access trojan (RAT) was detected via certutil attempting to decode an .inf file.

name: Bloodhound and Sharphound Hack Tools Detected
description: Command line parameters frequently used by Bloodhound and Sharphound tools were detected in your environment.

name: BloodHound Enumeration Activity
description: The BloodHound Enumeration Activity rules are used to identify potential domain enumeration activity from BloodHound or other Active Directory data collection tools. Any one or more of these will trigger the BloodHound Enumeration Activity alert type.

name: Bloodhound Tool Execution
description: Detects the execution of Bloodhound, a tool commonly used for mapping Active Directory (AD) trust relationships and identifying potential attack paths. Adversaries may use Bloodhound to analyze and exploit vulnerabilities within AD environments, facilitating privilege escalation and lateral movement. This activity is indicative of reconnaissance efforts that can precede more targeted attacks.

name: Box - Change Admin Role
description: A Box admin role was changed in your environment.

name: Box - Content Workflow Policy Violation
description: A Box Work flow policy violation was detected in your environment.

name: Box - File Marked Malicious
description: Box identified a potentially malicious file in your environment.

name: Box - Information Barrier Disabled
description: A Box Shield information barrier was deactivated.

name: Box - Shield Alert
description: Box Shield, detected potentially suspicious activity in your environment.

name: Box - Successful Login Outside the US
description: A Box user was seen logging in outside of the United States.

name: Browser Executing PuTTY and Launching Rundll32
description: Detects the execution of rundll32.exe by PuTTY.exe, a behavior that may suggest the misuse of legitimate software to execute unauthorized or malicious code. This activity is significant as it could be indicative of adversaries attempting to leverage PuTTY, a trusted SSH and telnet client, to run malicious scripts or payloads through the Windows host process. Such actions could be part of a broader strategy for initial access, privilege escalation, or lateral movement within a network. Monitoring this behavior helps identify potential security threats that exploit legitimate tools for malicious purposes.

name: Carbon Black - Detections
description: Stellar Cyber detected a suspicious alert originally reported by Carbon Black.

name: Carbon Black:XDR Anomaly
description: The Carbon Black endpoint generates an anomalously high amount of log data or a rarely seen type of log data on the host. Investigate the device and the user, to see if this is expected.

name: Certificate-Based Authentication Enabled
description: Detects when certificate based authentication has been enabled in an Azure Active Directory tenant.

name: Cisco Umbrella Malicious Site Access
description: Cisco Umbrella detected a connection to a potentially malicious domain.

name: Clear Windows RDP Event Log via Wevtutil Command Execution
description: Detects the execution of the wevtutil command to clear the Microsoft-Windows-TerminalServices-RDPClient/Operational event log on Windows endpoints. This activity typically uses command-line utilities such as powershell.exe or cmd.exe targeting the RDP client operational log. Adversaries may clear RDP logs to erase evidence of remote access or lateral movement. The rule triggers when process creation or command script events contain wevtutil with the cl flag and specify the RDP client log. This behavior is suspicious and may indicate attempts to cover tracks following unauthorized RDP activity.

name: Cloud Drive Data Exfiltration Anomaly
description: An account downloaded an atypical number of files over a 24-hour period. Check the user and the targeted files.

name: Command & Control Reputation Anomaly
description: An anomalously large number of connections were made to known command and control servers. Investigate the connections and source hosts. If malicious, block the IP addresses of the command and control servers.

name: Command Anomaly
description: A command has been executed an anomalously large number of times compared to its typical executions or those of other commands. Investigate the command and the user to determine if this is expected.

name: Compress Data and Lock With Password for Exfiltration With 7zip
description: Detects the use of 7zip to compress or encrypt data that is collected prior to exfiltration.

name: Compress Data and Lock With Password for Exfiltration With WINZIP
description: Detects the use of winzip to compress or encrypt data that is collected prior to exfiltration.

name: Conditional Access Blocked Login
description: A Conditional Access policy blocked a login attempt for a user in your environment,  check with the user identified if this was approved activity.

name: Conditional Access Policy Deleted
description: An Azure Conditional Access policy was deleted.

name: Consent to Suspicious Application
description: A user granted consent to an application that is a known suspicious OAUTH client, indicating potential malicious activity.

name: CrowdStrike - Detections
description: Stellar Cyber detected a suspicious alert originally reported by CrowdStrike.

name: Cryptojacking
description: An unauthorized coin miner used a computer to mine cryptocurrency. Consider blocking the source IP address.

name: Cybereason - Detections
description: Stellar Cyber detected a suspicious alert originally reported by Cybereason.

name: CylanceOPTICS:XDR Anomaly
description: The Cylance OPTICS endpoint generates an anomalously high amount of log data or a rarely seen type of log data on the host. Investigate the device and the user to see if this is expected.

name: CylancePROTECT - Detections
description: Stellar Cyber detected a suspicious alert originally reported by CylancePROTECT.

name: Cynet - Detections
description: Stellar Cyber detected a suspicious alert originally reported by Cynet.

name: Darktrace Detection
description: Darktrace detected potentially malicious activity in your environment.

name: Data Exfiltration to Text Storage Sites and Cloud Storage
description: A large amount of bytes were transferred to known text sites and cloud storage.

name: Data Ingestion Anomaly for Network and Security Sensors
Data Ingestion Volume Anomaly
description: A sensor is sending an anomalously high or low volume of data, compared to its typical volume. Check the sensor. A low volume could indicate a sensor failure or other problems. For a high volume, determine the cause of the increase.

name: DCERPC SMB Spoolss Named Pipe
description: The DCERPC SMB Spoolss Named Pipe rules detect suspicious SMB traffic accessing Spoolss named pipes. Any one or more of these will trigger the DCERPC SMB Spoolss Named Pipe alert type.

name: DeepInstinct - Detections
description: Stellar Cyber detected a suspicious alert originally reported by Deep Instinct.

name: Defender for Office 365 - Email Delivered from Malicious Sender Domain
description: This rule detects inbound emails delivered from malicious domains. It leverages the Microsoft Defender EmailEvents table to identify emails sent from domains that are flagged as malicious through Crowdstrike's IOC lookup function. By default, an IOC confidence level threshold of "medium" is being used, meaning that IOC has been associated with malicious activity within the last 120 days. Adjust the confidence level threshold as necessary.

name: Defender for Office 365 - Email Delivered from Malicious Sender IP Address
description: This rule detects inbound emails delivered from malicious sender IP addresses. It leverages the Microsoft Defender EmailEvents table to identify emails sent from IP addresses that are flagged as malicious through Crowdstrike's IOC lookup function. By default, an IOC confidence level threshold of "medium" is being used, meaning that IOC has been associated with malicious activity within the last 120 days. Adjust the confidence level threshold as necessary.

name: Defender for Office 365 - Email With Malicious URL
description: This rule detects malicious URLs within emails using Microsoft Defender data. It leverages the Microsoft Defender EmailUrlInfo table to identify emails sent from domains that are flagged as suspicious through Crowdstrike's IOC lookup function. By default, an IOC confidence level threshold of "medium" is being used, meaning that IOC has been associated with malicious activity within the last 120 days. Adjust the confidence level threshold as necessary.

name: Defender for Office 365 - High Confidence Phishing Email Delivered
description: This rule detects when emails identified as phishing with high confidence by Defender for Office 365 are successfully delivered to user inboxes. This behavior may indicate a potential bypass of phishing filters or a misconfiguration in email security settings.

name: Defender for Office 365 - URL Clicked with OAuth Device Code Login URL
description: This rule detects potential abuse of Microsoft's OAuth device code authentication flow. It monitors URL click events for specific device code login URLs that are known to be targeted by adversaries. The detection specifically tracks Microsoft's official OAuth device code flow URLs within the click event chain.

name: Device Registration or Join Without MFA
description: This rule identifies when secondary factor has not been provided during a risky authentication. Adversaries may look to bypass MFA controls by removing MFA devices or resetting factors. Best practice requires every user to be enrolled in MFA to ensure authentications have that extra step of validation.

name: DGA
description: A host is using a potential Domain Generation Algorithm (DGA). If the target domain is a malicious domain, the host might be compromised. Investigate the DGA domains and the host.

name: DHCP Server Anomaly
description: A new DHCP server appeared in the network. This could be a hacker attempting to steer traffic. Investigate and consider telling employees to avoid this server.

name: Direct Send Phishing Campaign Activity
description: A user received and accessed a malicious email associated with an ongoing direct send phishing campaign.

name: Discovery Using AzureHound
description: Detects AzureHound (A BloodHound data collector for Microsoft Azure) activity via the default User-Agent that is used during its operation after successful authentication.

name: DNS Exfiltration Tools Execution Detected
description: The execution of well known DNS exfiltration tools was detected.

name: DNS Query to Anonymous File Upload Domains
description: The DNS Query to Anonymous File Upload Domains rules are used to identify DNS queries to anonymous file upload platform domains often used for malicious purposes. Any one or more of these will trigger the DNS Query to Anonymous File Upload Domains alert type.

name: DNS Query to External Service Interaction Domains
description: The DNS Query to External Service Interaction Domains rules are used to identify DNS queries to external service interaction domains often used for out-of-band interactions after successful RCE. Any one or more of these will trigger the DNS Query to External Service Interaction Domains alert type.

name: DNS Query to Katz Stealer Domain
description: Detects DNS queries to domains associated with Katz Stealer malware. Katz Stealer is a malware variant that is known to be used for stealing sensitive information from compromised systems.

name: DNS Query to Monero Crypto Coin Mining Pool Domains
description: The DNS Query to Monero Crypto Coin Mining Pool Domains rules are used to identify DNS queries to Monero crypto coin mining pool domains. Any one or more of these will trigger the DNS Query to Monero Crypto Coin Mining Pool Domains alert type.

name: DNS Query to TOR Proxy Domain
description: The DNS Query to TOR Proxy Domain rules are used to identify DNS queries to onion domains and proxy domains for TOR network. Any one or more of these will trigger the DNS Query to TOR Proxy Domain alert type.

name: DNS Tunneling Anomaly
description: An anomalously large number of connections tunneling high-entropy traffic through DNS were made. This can indicate data exfiltration. Investigate the tunnel and source host. If malicious, block the source host.

name: DPAPI Domain Backup Key Extraction
description: An attempt to extract the LSA secret DPAPI domain backup key from domain  controllers was detected.

name: Duo Fraud Impossible Travel Correlation
description: Detects a correlation between Duo fraud events with Impossible travel activity.

name: Duo Login Outside the US
description: A successful login outside the US was detected for the following Duo user.

name: Duo Security Failed Authentication
description: A user failed a Duo Security authentication.

name: Duo User Bypass Status Update
description: A Duo user was added to bypass status, allowing the user to login without MFA.

name: Duo User Marked as Fraud
description: Detects reported Duo fraud attempts by the user.

name: Emerging Threat
description: An emerging threat has been observed. Investigate the IP address, domain name, URL, or file hashes (MD5, SHA1, SHA256) and consider blocking.

name: Emerging Threat
description: An emerging threat has been observed. Investigate the IP address, domain name, URL, or file hashes (MD5, SHA1, SHA256) and consider blocking.

name: Emotet Loader Execution Via .LNK File
description: Activity associated with known Emotet loader techniques was detected in your environment.

name: Encoded PowerShell
description: A Windows host executed an encoded PowerShell script. Investigate the script contents to see if it is malicious. If so, consider quarantining the host.

name: Encrypted C&C
description: A connection to or from known command and control servers was observed in encrypted traffic. Consider blocking the source IP address.

name: Entra ID - Admin Assigned High Privilege Permissions to an Application
description: This rule identifies instances where administrative user accounts grant new high privilege permissions to applications in Entra ID. It monitors for consent actions that elevate an application's access rights to sensitive data or resources. This behavior could indicate a potential security threat, as attackers often create or modify applications with elevated permissions to gain widespread access across the environment after compromising an admin account.

name: Entra ID - Admin Deleted MFA Authentication Method
description: Identifies instances of MFA Authentication methods (Microsoft Authenticator App, Email, SMS, Temporary One Time Password (TOTP) Application) that have been removed from a user by an administrator. Adversaries use this technique to take over legitimate accounts by removing existing authentication mechanism after adding their own.

name: Entra ID - All Domains Allowed in Collaboration Restrictions
description: Identifies when Entra ID external collaboration settings are changed to allow invitations to be sent to any domain. This is the default configuration for this policy for a new Entra ID tenant. If the policy has been changed to be more restrictive, this change sets it back to default. This policy change is concerning because it enables collaboration invitations to any external domain, allowing adversaries to add their own domains and invite external accounts under their control. Consequently, adversaries can interact with resources within the organization's domain and potentially gain prolonged backdoor access as external collaborators. This rule helps security teams quickly identify and respond to this high-risk policy change in Entra ID, which could be exploited for unauthorized access and data exfiltration.

name: Entra ID - Application With Newly Modified Credentials Adding Roles to Identities
description: This rule identifies instances where an Entra ID application's credentials were updated within the last 7 days and subsequently monitors for any new role assignment events created by that application. This behavior could indicate unauthorized access or manipulation of the application's permissions. The risk involves potential account takeover, data exfiltration, or the creation of backdoor accounts by malicious actors who have gained control of the application's credentials.

name: Entra ID - Application With Newly Modified Credentials Observed Creating New Users
description: This rule identifies instances where an Entra ID application's credentials were updated within the last 7 days and subsequently monitors for any new user creation events by that application. This behavior could indicate unauthorized access or manipulation of the application's permissions. The risk involves potential account takeover, data exfiltration, or the creation of backdoor accounts by malicious actors who have gained control of the application's credentials.

name: Entra ID - Application/Service Principal Credentials Updated by SP
description: Identifies changes to client credentials (secrets or certificates) assigned to a Microsoft Entra application or service principals, when action is performed by another service principal. Service principals are special identities used to govern access to resources within a Microsoft Entra tenant for applications, services, and automated tools. Due to their programmatic nature, service principals do not support multi-factor authentication. An adversary that established an initial foothold into cloud infrastructure may be attempting to manipulate applications and service principals by adding rogue secrets or certificates to maintain access or elevate privileges. By gaining control of such objects, an adversary might be able to establish persistence and widen access to progress towards their attack goals. Specific enterprise applications (like Managed Service Identity, or Azure AD Application Proxy) are expected to update service principal credentials. To get accurate detections, it is recommended to identify such applications and exclude them from search results based on object ID.

name: Entra ID - Application/Service Principal Credentials Updated by User
description: Identifies changes to client credentials (secrets or certificates) assigned to a Microsoft Entra application or service principal, when action is performed by a user. Service principals are special identities used to govern access to resources within a Microsoft Entra tenant for applications, services, and automated tools. Due to their programmatic nature, service principals do not support multi-factor authentication. An adversary that established an initial foothold into cloud infrastructure may be attempting to manipulate applications and service principals by adding rogue secrets or certificates to maintain access or elevate privileges. By gaining control of such objects, an adversary might be able to establish persistence and widen access to progress towards their attack goals. Application / service principal client credentials modifications are expected as part of legitimate administrative or development operations. Apply exclusions for legitimate activity as needed.

name: Entra ID - Application/Service Principal Owner Added by SP
description: Detects when a new owner is added to an application registration or service principal object, and action is performed by another service principal. Service principals are special identities used to govern access to resources within a Microsoft Entra tenant for applications, services, and automated tools. Due to their programmatic nature, service principals do not support multi-factor authentication. An adversary that established an initial foothold into cloud infrastructure may be attempting to get ownership of application registrations or service principals to leverage their granted permissions, modify configuration and alter behavior. By gaining control of such objects, an adversary might be able to establish persistence and widen access to progress towards their attack goals. Specific enterprise applications (like Power Virtual Agents Service) are expected to create new applications and set application / service principal ownership upon creation. To get accurate detections, it is recommended to identify such applications and exclude them from search results based on object ID.

name: Entra ID - Application/Service Principal Owner Added by User
description: Detects when a new owner is added to an application registration or service principal object, and action is performed by a user. Service principals are special identities used to govern access to resources within a Microsoft Entra tenant for applications, services, and automated tools. Due to their programmatic nature, service principals do not support multi-factor authentication. An adversary that established an initial foothold into cloud infrastructure may be attempting to get ownership of application registrations or service principals to leverage their granted permissions, modify configuration and alter behavior. By gaining control of such objects, an adversary might be able to establish persistence and widen access to progress towards their attack goals. Application / service principals ownership is expected to be updated when created or as part of administrative activity. Apply exclusions as needed.

name: Entra ID - Bitlocker Key Retrieval
description: This rule identifies when a user attempts to get BitLocker keys stored in Entra ID. A user retrieving these keys is unusual and should be reviewed.

name: Entra ID - Bulk Download Devices List
description: This detection rule identifies instances of bulk Intune device enumeration in Entra ID. It detects when a large-scale download of Intune device information occurs, a behavior commonly observed in cloud environment compromises. Adversaries often perform this action to gather a comprehensive list of potential targets for further exploitation within the organization's cloud infrastructure.

name: Entra ID - Bulk Download Groups List
description: This detection rule identifies instances of bulk groups enumeration in Entra ID. It identifies when a large-scale download of tenant group information occurs, a behavior commonly observed in cloud environment compromises. Adversaries often perform this action to gather a comprehensive list of potential targets for further exploitation within the organization's cloud infrastructure.

name: Entra ID - Bulk Download Service Principals List
description: This detection rule identifies instances of bulk service principal enumeration in Entra ID. It identifies when a large-scale download of tenant service principal information occurs, a behavior commonly observed in cloud environment compromises. Adversaries often perform this action to gather a comprehensive list of potential applications for further exploitation within the organization's cloud infrastructure.

name: Entra ID - Bulk Download User List
description: This detection rule identifies instances of bulk user enumeration in Entra ID. It identifies when a large-scale download of tenant user information occurs, a behavior commonly observed in cloud environment compromises. Adversaries often perform this action to gather a comprehensive list of potential targets for further exploitation within the organization's cloud infrastructure.

name: Entra ID - CA Policy Removed by Non Approved Actor - Sigma
description: Monitor and alert on conditional access changes where non approved actor removed CA Policy.

name: Entra ID - CA Policy Updated by Non Approved Actor - Sigma
description: Monitor and alert on conditional access changes. Is Initiated by (actor) approved to make changes? Review Modified Properties and compare "old" vs "new" value.

name: Entra ID - Conditional Access Policy Bypass via Intune Company Portal App
description: This rule identifies potential Conditional Access Policy (CAP) bypasses in Microsoft Entra ID, specifically for the Microsoft Intune Company Portal application. It detects instances where device compliance requirements fail, yet authentication succeeds. This pattern suggests a possible bypass technique, risking unauthorized access to corporate resources by circumventing intended security controls.

name: Entra ID - Cross Tenant Partner Given Inbound Access
description: This rule detects the modification of cross-tenant access settings to allow inbound access to other tenants. Adversary may utilize this technique to access sensitive information through compromised partner tenants.

name: Entra ID - Cross-tenant Access Settings Organization Modified
description: Detection identifies when an Azure tenant administrator adds or removes a partner to the cross-tenant access settings, which could be indicative of a lateral movement or backdoor attempt. This analytic focuses specifically on the action of modifying Azure Cross-Tenant Synchronization configurations, which attackers might exploit to gain unauthorized access across multiple tenant environments.

name: Entra ID - Customer Identity Access Management Access Policy Modification
description: This rule identifies when a customer identity and access management (CIAM) access policy is modified. Access policies should be reviewed and go through proper change management processes to ensure no degradation of access occurs.

name: Entra ID - Domain Added to Collaboration Restrictions Allow List
description: Identifies when new domains are added to the external collaboration allow list in Microsoft Entra ID. Adversaries might add domains to the allow list to facilitate unauthorized access, data exfiltration, or command and control communications. By allowing their own malicious domains, adversaries can bypass security controls, and establish persistence while appearing as legitimate external collaborators. This action could be a critical step in expanding their attack surface and maintaining long-term access to the organization's resources.

name: Entra ID - Domain Added to Collaboration Restrictions Deny List
description: Identifies addition of domains to the external collaboration deny list in Microsoft Entra ID. It triggers an alert when a new domain is added to the list of blocked domains for external collaboration invitations. Adversaries might add domains to the external collaboration deny list to isolate an organization, bypass security measures, misdirect users, disrupt incident response, or facilitate social engineering attacks. This action can help attackers maintain persistence, control data flow, and hinder detection, making it a potentially powerful tool in their arsenal for compromising an organization's security operations.

name: Entra ID - Entra Connect Account Anomalous Behaviour
description: This rule detects potential compromise of Entra Connect accounts used for federated access to on-premises Active Directory servers. It identifies anomalous access patterns, including logins from unexpected applications, access to non-standard resources, or use of authentication protocols other than ROPC.

name: Entra ID - ESX Admins Group Created
description: An adversary can create an Active Directory group named "ESX Admins" to gain privileged access to ESXi infrastructure, by exploiting vulnerabilities such as CVE-2024-37085.

name: Entra ID - External Organization Connected to Directory
description: This rule detects the addition of connected organization in Microsoft Entra ID. In conjunction with an access package, this can allow users in the external organization/directory to access internal resources. Adversaries may utilize this technique for intial access and persistence.

name: Entra ID - Global Administrator Role Assigned
description: Identifies the assignment of the Microsoft Entra ID Global Administrator role to a user. This privileged role provides access to all administrative features of Microsoft Entra ID and Microsoft services that use Microsoft Entra identities. Since this role could allow an attacker to maintain access, escalate privileges and modify almost every administrative setting in Microsoft Entra and Microsoft 365, it should be assigned to very few people in your organization to keep the attack surface low.

name: Entra ID - Guest Invite Restrictions Policy Change
description: Identifies changes to the Guest Invite Settings of your Entra ID tenant. These settings determine which users can invite external members (guests) to join your organization. When these settings are modified, it affects how your organization manages and controls the process of bringing in guest users.

name: Entra ID - Guest Promoted to Member
description: This rule identifies when a guest account is changed to a member of the tenant. This is highly unusual to occur as guest users are 3rd party users supporting business operations in some way. A 3rd party user should not be promoted to an official member of a tenant under normal circumstances.

name: Entra ID - Guest User Access Restriction Security Posture Downgraded
description: Identifies changes to the Entra ID Guest User Access restriction policy. In particular, this rule will identify when the policy posture is downgrade by changing from "Guest user access is restricted to properties and memberships of their own directory objects (most restrictive)" to either "Guest users have limited access to properties and memberships of directory objects" or "Guest users have the same access as members (most inclusive)". Additionally, another posture downgrade can occur when the setting changes from "Guest users have limited access to properties and memberships of directory objects" to "Guest users have the same access as members (most inclusive)".

name: Entra ID - Known Suspicious OAuth Clients
description: Detects when an OAuth consent is granted or attempted for an application known to be linked to Business Email Compromise (BEC) attacks, phishing campaigns, or associated with suspicious behavior. These applications can be leveraged by adversaries to access and exfiltrate sensitive information, such as mailbox content, contacts, or calendar data pertaining to a compromised account. Furthermore, granting consent to these applications can also enable persistence, allowing adversaries to maintain access to a user's mailbox even after a password reset. Failures are also detected, meaning that a consent was attempted but blocked by Microsoft Entra ID user consent settings, which may indicate that an account is at risk.

name: Entra ID - Member Added to ESX Admins Group
description: An attacker can add a new member to an Active Directory group named "ESX Admins" to gain privileged access to ESXi infrastructure through the CVE-2024-37085 vulnerability.

name: Entra ID - MFA Disabled for Single User
description: Detects when multi-factor authentication (MFA) is disabled for a single user account. Turning off MFA removes an essential security layer, exposing user accounts to a higher risk of compromise. An adversary that established an initial foothold into cloud infrastructure may leverage their access to modify or completely disable MFA mechanisms to achieve persistence, widen access, and progress towards their attack goals.

name: Entra ID - MFA Fraud Reported by End User
description: This detection rule identifies instances where users report unexpected Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) prompts, potentially indicating account compromise. It monitors for user-initiated fraud reports through authentication apps like Microsoft Authenticator, where users flag MFA requests they didn't initiate. Such behavior often signifies an attacker possessing valid credentials attempting to access the account, possibly employing MFA fatigue attack techniques to bypass additional security layers.

name: Entra ID - MS Graph Application Permission Assigned to Service Principal by SP
description: Detects when a new Microsoft Graph application permission (also known as app role) is assigned to a service principal identity, and action is performed by another service principal. Service principals are special identities used to govern access to resources within a Microsoft Entra tenant for applications, services, and automated tools. Due to their programmatic nature, service principals do not support multi-factor authentication. When a given application permission is assigned, the service principal is granted with full and unconstrained access to all resources and operations governed by that permission. For example, a service principal granted with “Mail.Read” permission will be able to read emails in all mailboxes without a signed-in user. An adversary that established an initial foothold into cloud infrastructure may be attempting to assign new permissions to applications and service principals under their control, or take advantage of sensitive permissions that were previously granted to registered applications to widen access and progress towards their attack goals. There are limited use cases where specific enterprise applications are known to assign Microsoft Graph permissions to other identities. While exclusions can be applied, it is important to maintain visibility to such assignments and ensure that the least privilege principle is applied when granting permissions to service principals.

name: Entra ID - MS Graph Application Permission Assigned to Service Principal by User
description: Detects when a new Microsoft Graph application permission (also known as app role) is assigned to a service principal identity, and action is performed by a user. Service principals are special identities used to govern access to resources within a Microsoft Entra tenant for applications, services, and automated tools. Due to their programmatic nature, service principals do not support multi-factor authentication. When a given application permission is assigned, the service principal is granted with full and unconstrained access to all resources and operations governed by that permission. For example, a service principal granted with “Mail.Read” permission will be able to read emails in all mailboxes without a signed-in user. An adversary that established an initial foothold into cloud infrastructure may be attempting to assign new permissions to applications and service principals under their control, or take advantage of sensitive permissions that were previously granted to registered applications to widen access and progress towards their attack goals. Specific enterprise applications require Microsoft Graph application permissions for their normal operation. While exclusions might be applied for some events, it is important to maintain visibility to such assignments and ensure that the least privilege principle is applied when granting permissions to service principals.

name: Entra ID - Multiple Failed Login Attempts by Single User
description: This rule detects multiple failed sign-in attempts for a single user account in Microsoft Entra ID, indicating that account is subject to bruteforce attempt or part of a password spray attack targeting multiple accounts. By default, this rule uses a threshold of 5 failed sign-in attempts within search window. Adjust this threshold based on your organization's typical authentication patterns, security policies, and risk tolerance to avoid false positives.

name: Entra ID - New Authentication Domain Added
description: Detects when a new custom domain is added to an Entra ID tenant. This modifications in tangent with creating a secondary signing certificate can allow adversaries to authenticate as any user by signing their own tokens.

name: Entra ID - New CA Policy by Non-approved Actor - Sigma
description: Monitor and alert on conditional access changes.

name: Entra ID - New MFA Device Operating System Observed
description: This rule detects when a new mobile operating system is observed for a user that differs from their normal usage pattern. During post-compromise activities, an adversary may register an additional MFA factor to gain long-term persistence. For example, this rule will fire when a user typically only uses either iOS or Android devices for their MFA requests, but suddenly a mix of both Android and iOS devices are observed for their account.

name: Entra ID - New User Observed Consenting to new Application
description: This rule detects potentially malicious application consent grants by newly created accounts in Microsoft Entra ID. The detection specifically monitors for user accounts that are created and subsequently perform application consent operations within 7 days, which could indicate an attacker establishing persistence through an OAuth app after compromising or creating new user accounts. This technique is particularly dangerous as malicious actors can leverage OAuth permissions to maintain long-term access to resources independently of user credentials, potentially leading to data exfiltration or further account compromise.

name: Entra ID - Password Spray Detection by Source IP
description: Identify patterns consistent with password spray attacks by looking for sign-in failures for multiple accounts, originating from the same source IP address within a time window. Password spraying can be conducted by an adversary against Microsoft's cloud-based identity and access management service (Entra ID) to establish an initial foothold into cloud infrastructure. If successful at this step, the adversary might be seeking to leverage the compromised accounts to widen access and progress towards their attack goals. Sign-in failure codes in scope: 50053 (account is locked, or blocked because it came from an IP address with malicious activity), 50126 (invalid username or password), 50055 (password is expired), and 50057 (account is disabled). Default threshold for distinct accounts per source IP: 10

name: Entra ID - Potential Adversary-in-the-Middle Login Sequence
description: This rule detects potential Adversary-in-the-Middle (AiTM) phishing attacks targeting Microsoft Entra ID by monitoring sign-in patterns and error codes that could indicate credential theft attempts. The rule analyzes login attempts into specific Office applications where users experience a sequence of authentication challenges or failures followed by a successful login, which is a common pattern in AiTM attacks where adversaries proxy authentication requests through malicious infrastructure. The risk associated with these attacks include credential theft, session token hijacking, and potential unauthorized access to Microsoft 365 resources even when MFA is enabled.

name: Entra ID - Potential Brute Force Attack through Azure Powershell
description: This rule identifies a potential brute force attack through Azure PowerShell by monitoring for multiple failed authentication attempts using the Microsoft Azure PowerShell application. Adversaries may attempt to brute force credentials to gain access to Azure resources.

name: Entra ID - Potential Successful Brute Force Attack from Single IP
description: This rule detects potential brute force attacks against Microsoft Entra ID accounts by identifying instances where a single user account experiences more than 100 authentication failures within a 1-hour time window from the same IP address, with at least one successful login attempt. This pattern may indicate that an adversary has successfully guessed an account's password, potentially leading to unauthorized access.

name: Entra ID - Potential Successful Password Spray Attack
description: This rule detects potential password spraying attacks by identifying instances where multiple Entra ID user accounts experience at least a single successful login attempt, preceded by a series of authentication failures, within a 1-hour time window. This pattern may indicate that an adversary is attempting to gain access to multiple accounts using a commonly used password or a list of known passwords. Activity is clustered by Autonomous System (AS) as adversaries might be using different IP addresses to execute the attack and try to evade traditional brute force protections.

name: Entra ID - Primary Refresh Token Abuse Defaults
description: Detects when a new device is registered with a Windows version (10.0.19041.928) associated with an attacker generating a Primary Refresh Token.

name: Entra ID - Primary Refresh Token Abuse using Authentication Broker
description: Detects when authentication with the Microsoft Authentication Broker App ID is used with certain resources. This may indicate an attacker has generated a Primary Refresh Token.

name: Entra ID - Privileged Azure Role Assigned to Group in PIM as Eligible Assignment
description: Detects when a privileged Azure-based role is assigned to a group via Microsoft Entra Privileged Identity Management (PIM) as an eligible assignment, potentially elevating one or more identities permissions and increasing the attack surface. This rule helps identify potential security risks and ensures compliance with least privilege access principles. An adversary who has established an initial foothold in cloud infrastructure may attempt to assign new roles or take advantage of roles and permissions previously granted to groups under their control. By default, this rule detects any assignment where the target identity is a group and is assigned a role labeled as Privileged, as observed in Azure IAM. While specific users require certain permissions for their normal operations, and exclusions can be applied for some events, it is important to maintain visibility of such assignments and ensure that the principle of least privilege is applied.

name: Entra ID - Privileged Azure Role Assigned to User in PIM as Eligible Assignment
description: Detects when a privileged Azure-based role is assigned to a user via Microsoft Entra Privileged Identity Management (PIM) as an eligible assignment, potentially elevating the user's permissions and increasing the attack surface. This rule helps identify potential security risks and ensures compliance with least privilege access principles. An adversary who has established an initial foothold in cloud infrastructure may attempt to assign new roles or take advantage of roles and permissions previously granted to users under their control. By default, this rule detects any assignment where the target identity is a user and is assigned a role labeled as Privileged, as observed in Azure IAM. While specific users require certain permissions for their normal operations, and exclusions can be applied for some events, it is important to maintain visibility of such assignments and ensure that the principle of least privilege is applied.

name: Entra ID - Privileged Identity Management Modifications
description: This rule identifies when a Privileged Identity Management (PIM) policy has been modified for a highly privileged role. If an attacker has access to modify PIM settings, they may weaken an organization's security controls.

name: Entra ID - Privileged Role Assigned to Group in PIM as Active Assignment
description: Detects when a privileged role is assigned to a Microsoft Entra role-assignable group via Privileged Identity Management (PIM) service, as active assignment (not recommended by best practices, and in contrast to eligible assignments which require on-demand activation). This rule helps identify potential security risks resulting from PIM active role assignments to groups, and to ensure compliance with least privilege access principles. An adversary who has established an initial foothold in cloud infrastructure may attempt to assign privileged roles to role-assignable groups in Microsoft Entra ID, or exploit previously granted roles and permissions, to elevate privileges for group member accounts under their control. By default, this rule triggers on any assignment where the target identity is a role-assignable group, and the assigned role name contains 'Administrator' or matches any other privileged built-in role, as listed at https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference#all-roles. Additional roles can be included as needed. Specific groups of accounts require certain permissions for their normal operation. While exclusions can be applied for some events, it is important to maintain visibility to such assignments and ensure that the least privilege principle is applied.

name: Entra ID - Privileged Role Assigned to Group in PIM as Eligible Assignment
description: Detects when a privileged role is assigned as eligible to a Microsoft Entra role-assignable group via Privileged Identity Management (PIM) service, allowing group members to activate the role and potentially elevate their access and privileges. This rule helps identify potential security risks resulting from privileged role assignments to groups, and to ensure compliance with least privilege access principles. An adversary who has established an initial foothold in cloud infrastructure may attempt to assign privileged roles to groups, or take advantage of previously granted roles and permissions, to elevate privileges for group member accounts under their control. By default, this rule triggers on any assignment where the target identity is a role-assignable group, and the assigned role name contains 'Administrator' or matches any other privileged built-in role, as listed at https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference#all-roles. Additional roles can be included as needed. Specific groups of accounts require certain permissions for their normal operation. While exclusions can be applied for some events, it is important to maintain visibility to such assignments and ensure that the least privilege principle is applied.

name: Entra ID - Privileged Role Assigned to Group outside of PIM
description: Detects when a privileged role is assigned to a Microsoft Entra role-assignable group, where the assignment action is performed outside of the Privileged Identity Management (PIM) service. As a best practice for robust identity and access management, it is recommended that privileged roles be managed exclusively within PIM to minimize the risk of unauthorized access. An adversary who has established an initial foothold in cloud infrastructure may attempt to assign privileged roles to groups, or take advantage of previously granted roles and permissions, to elevate privileges for group member accounts under their control. By default, this rule triggers on any assignment where the target identity is a Microsoft Entra role-assignable group, and the assigned role name contains 'Administrator' or matches any other privileged built-in role, as listed at https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference#all-roles. Additional roles can be included as needed. For a broader detection of any role assignment outside of PIM (not limited to privileged roles), remove the indicated lines in the query string.

name: Entra ID - Privileged Role Assigned to Service Principal in PIM
description: Detects when a privileged role is assigned to a Service Principal via Microsoft Entra Privileged Identity Management (PIM) as active assignment, potentially elevating the service principal's permissions and increasing the attack surface. This rule helps identify potential security risks and to ensure compliance with least privilege access principles. Service principals are special identities used to govern access to resources within a Microsoft Entra tenant for applications, services, and automated tools. Due to their programmatic nature, service principals do not support multi-factor authentication. Also, service principals do not support eligible assignments in PIM. When a given role is assigned, the service principal is granted full and unconstrained access to all resources and operations governed by that role. For example, a service principal granted with "Exchange Administrator" role will be able to manage all aspects of the Exchange product. An adversary that established an initial foothold into cloud infrastructure may be attempting to assign new roles or take advantage of roles and permissions that were previously granted to service principals under their control. By default, this rule will detect any assignment where the target identity is a service principal, and assigned role name contains "Administrator", or matches any other privileged built-in role as listed by https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference#all-roles. Additional roles can be included as needed. Specific enterprise applications / service principals require certain permissions for their normal operation. While exclusions can be applied for some events, it is important to maintain visibility to such assignments and ensure that the least privilege principle is applied.

name: Entra ID - Privileged Role Assigned to Service Principal outside of PIM
description: Detects when a privileged role is assigned to a Service Principal in Microsoft Entra ID, where the assignment action is performed outside of the Privileged Identity Management (PIM) service, potentially elevating the service principal's permissions and increasing the attack surface. This rule helps identify potential security risks and to ensure compliance with least privilege access principles. Service principals are special identities used to govern access to resources within a Microsoft Entra tenant for applications, services, and automated tools. Due to their programmatic nature, service principals do not support multi-factor authentication. When a given role is assigned, the service principal is granted full and unconstrained access to all resources and operations governed by that role. For example, a service principal granted with "Exchange Administrator" role will be able to manage all aspects of the Exchange product. An adversary that established an initial foothold into cloud infrastructure may be attempting to assign new roles or take advantage of roles and permissions that were previously granted to service principals under their control. By default, this rule will detect any assignment where the target identity is a service principal, and assigned role name contains "Administrator", or matches any other privileged built-in role as listed by https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference#all-roles. Additional roles can be included as needed. For a broader detection of any role assignment outside of PIM (not limited to privileged roles), remove the indicated line in the query string. Specific enterprise applications / service principals require certain permissions for their normal operation. While exclusions can be applied for some events, it is important to maintain visibility to such assignments and ensure that the least privilege principle is applied.

name: Entra ID - Privileged Role Assigned to User Account in PIM as Active Assignment
description: Detects when a privileged role is assigned to a user account in Microsoft Entra ID via Privileged Identity Management (PIM) service, as active assignment (not recommended by best practices, and in contrast to eligible assignments which require on-demand activation). This rule helps identify potential security risks resulting from PIM active role assignments and helps ensure compliance with least privilege access principles. An adversary who has established an initial foothold in cloud infrastructure may attempt to assign new roles or exploit previously granted roles and permissions to accounts under their control. By default, this rule triggers on any assignment where the target identity is a user account, and the assigned role name contains 'Administrator' or matches any other privileged built-in role, as listed at https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference#all-roles. Additional roles can be included as needed. Specific accounts require certain permissions for their normal operation. While exclusions can be applied for some events, it is important to maintain visibility to such assignments and ensure that the least privilege principle is applied.

name: Entra ID - Privileged Role Assigned to User Account in PIM as Eligible Assignment
description: Detects when a privileged role is assigned as eligible to a user account via Privileged Identity Management (PIM) service, allowing the user to activate the role and potentially elevate their access and privileges. This rule helps identify potential security risks and ensures compliance with least privilege access principles. An adversary that established an initial foothold into cloud infrastructure may attempt to escalate their privileges by assigning new eligible roles to accounts under their control, or activating roles that were assigned previously via PIM. By default, this rule will detect any assignment where role name contains "Administrator", or matches any other privileged built-in role as listed by https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference#all-roles. Additional roles can be included as needed. Specific accounts require certain permissions for their normal operation. While exclusions can be applied for some events, it is important to maintain visibility to such assignments and ensure that the least privilege principle is applied.

name: Entra ID - Privileged Role Assigned to User Account outside of PIM
description: Detects when a privileged role is assigned to a user account in Microsoft Entra ID, where the assignment action is performed outside of the Privileged Identity Management (PIM) service. As a best practice for robust identity and access management, it is recommended that privileged roles be managed exclusively within PIM to minimize the risk of unauthorized access. An adversary who has established an initial foothold in cloud infrastructure may attempt to assign new roles or exploit previously granted roles and permissions to accounts under their control. By default, this rule triggers on any assignment where the target identity is a user account, and the assigned role name contains 'Administrator' or matches any other privileged built-in role, as listed at https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference#all-roles. Additional roles can be included as needed. For a broader detection of any role assignment outside of PIM (not limited to privileged roles), remove the indicated line in the query string.

name: Entra ID - Risky Application Consent Observed
description: This rule identifies applications labeled as risky by Microsoft during the consent process. An application's risk level is determined by multiple factors that include the specific permissions requested or lack of a verified publisher. This rule also takes into account successful and failed user and administrator consent actions which should be interesting to observe as consenting to applications is a relatively uncommon occurrence for risky applications.

name: Entra ID - Risky Sign-in
description: Identifies a successful Microsoft Entra ID sign-in that has been categorized as medium or high risk by Microsoft Entra ID Identity Protection, indicating a potential compromised account being abused by a threat actor or other suspicious activity. Microsoft Entra ID Identity Protection assigns a risk value of low, medium, or high to sign-in events based on real-time signals and also calculates an aggregate risk value for the user account. By default, this rule detects sign-in events where either the real-time sign-in risk or the aggregate user risk is categorized as medium or high.

name: Entra ID - Risky Sign-in via CLI Tools
description: This rule identifies when a successful or risky authentication is observed from privileged Azure resources. These resources are leveraged to perform operations on the Azure tenant and utilization of these resources should be reviewed.

name: Entra ID - Security Group Renamed to ESX Admins
description: An attacker can create an Active Directory group named "ESX Admins" to gain privileged access to ESXi infrastructure through the CVE-2024-37085 vulnerability. In addition to creating a new group, an attacker could rename an existing group to achive the same effect.

name: Entra ID - Service Principal Granted Full Access to Exchange Web Services
description: This rule identifies applications labeled as risky by Microsoft during the consent process. An application's risk level is determined by multiple factors that include the specific permissions requested or lack of a verified publisher. This rule also takes into account successful and failed user and administrator consent actions which should be interesting to observe as consenting to applications is a relatively uncommon occurrence for risky applications.

name: Entra ID - Service Principal Sign-in from Suspicious IP Address
description: Identifies successful sign-in events for Service Principal identities in Microsoft Entra ID, where source IP address is flagged as malicious or suspicious by CrowdStrike's threat intelligence feed. This rule helps identify potential compromises of Service Principal identities followed by unauthorized access attempts from known adversarial infrastructure. By default, an IOC confidence level threshold of "unverified" is being used, meaning that IOC has been reported but not yet verified. Adjust the confidence level threshold as necessary. For more information about ioc:lookup function, see https://library.humio.com/data-analysis/functions-ioc-lookup.html. This rule template is not compatible with Data Connector built for Microsoft Graph API since service principal sign-in events are not collected by current implementation of data connector.

name: Entra ID - Short Lived Account
description: Identifies successful sign-in events for Service Principal identities in Microsoft Entra ID, where source IP address is flagged as malicious or suspicious by CrowdStrike's threat intelligence feed. This rule helps identify potential compromises of Service Principal identities followed by unauthorized access attempts from known adversarial infrastructure. By default, an IOC confidence level threshold of "unverified" is being used, meaning that IOC has been reported but not yet verified. Adjust the confidence level threshold as necessary. For more information about ioc:lookup function, see https://library.humio.com/data-analysis/functions-ioc-lookup.html. This rule template is not compatible with Data Connector built for Microsoft Graph API since service principal sign-in events are not collected by current implementation of data connector.

name: Entra ID - SMS MFA Primary Phone Number Country Code Change
description: Detects when a user's primary SMS multi-factor authentication (MFA) phone number is modified to have a different country code. Attackers often change the MFA phone number associated with a compromised account to a number they control. This allows them to receive the MFA codes and maintain persistent access to the account. The rule parses and compares the country codes of the old and new phone numbers. If the country codes are different, it triggers an alert. This indicates a potential account compromise where the attacker has changed the MFA phone number to one in a different country.

name: Entra ID - Successful Authentication from Malicious IP Address
description: Identifies successful authentication events via Microsoft Entra ID originating from IP addresses flagged as malicious by CrowdStrike's threat intelligence feed (medium or high confidence). This rule helps identify potential account compromises and unauthorized access attempts from known adversarial infrastructure.

name: Entra ID - Successful Authentication Without MFA
description: This rule identifies when secondary factor has not been provided during a risky authentication. Adversaries may look to bypass MFA controls by removing MFA devices or resetting factors. Best practice requires every user to be enrolled in MFA to ensure authentications have that extra step of validation.

name: Entra ID - Suspicious Device Code SignIn via Microsoft Authentication Broker
description: This rule identifies suspicious Microsoft Entra ID sign-in events where Device Code authentication flow is being used via Microsoft Authentication Broker application. The Device Code flow is a risky authentication mechanism that can be exploited by attackers in phishing campaigns, tricking users into authenticating with a device code and their credentials. This activity is concerning because it could allow adversaries to gain a Primary Refresh Token by registering a device with the domain. This correlation rule template is not compatible with Data Connector built for Microsoft Graph API since authenticationProtocol data field is not returned by current implementation of Graph API endpoint.

name: Entra ID - Suspicious Intune Enrollment
description: Detects when a new device is enrolled with Intune using a Python package related user agent and the Microsoft Authentication Broker app. This is default in some tooling and can be a indicitive of a threat actor generating a Primary Refresh Token.

name: Entra ID - Suspicious Issuer Address Observed in Application or Service Principal
description: This rule detects the addition of a federated identity credential to a service principal or application registration, a tactic that adversaries may use to persist in an environment. This rule compares each issuer URL against CrowdStrike's threat intelligence indicator list and generates an alert if a match is found. For instance, adding a federated identity credential to a user-assigned managed identity service principal could potentially allow an adversary to authenticate and obtain an access token for the tenant from outside an Azure-owned resource. This attack would require the adversary to already possess high privileges within the tenant or have prior ownership of a service principal, granting them the ability to add credentials to applications.

name: Entra ID - Suspicious MFA Email Registration
description: This rule detects when an unexpected email address is registered for Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) in Microsoft Entra ID. The rule identifies email addresses that are not associated with organization's domain names or not authorized for MFA use, which may indicate a potential security risk. This could be a sign of an adversary attempting to gain unauthorized access to a user account or a user inadvertently registering an unauthorized email address for MFA. An adversary that established an initial foothold into cloud infrastructure may be attempting to modify multi-factor authentication properties to enable persistent access to compromised accounts. To get accurate detections, exclude expected patterns by adding an additional filter at the end of the query string (e.g. "| emailAddress!=/@(example\.net|example\.com)$/i").

name: Entra ID - Suspicious Reply URL Observed in Application or Service Principal
description: This rule detects potential OAuth illicit consent grant attacks by identifying new or updated applications and service principals with suspicious reply/redirect URL's, as flagged by CrowdStrike's threat intelligence indicator list. This behavior might be indicative of a successful phishing attack where an adversary tricks a user into consenting to malicious applications, resulting in a service principal being added to the tenant and a token being sent to the adversary for use on behalf of the victim. The rule also monitors for updated applications and service principals to catch adversaries hijacking existing or new applications for further phishing purposes.

name: Entra ID - Temporary Access Pass Added to User Account
description: Detects when a Temporary Access Pass (TAP) is registered for a user account. A TAP is a time-limited passcode that satisfies Microsoft Entra strong authentication requirements, like multi-factor authentication requirements implemented by conditional access policies. An adversary that established an initial foothold into cloud infrastructure may be attempting to compromise privileged accounts by registering and using TAPs. Account owners won’t be alerted about this change and their existing password and registered MFA mechanisms will continue to work properly. By gaining control of privileged accounts, an adversary might be able to establish additional persistence, widen access, and progress towards their attack goals. By default, all TAP registration events are detected. To limit the detection scope to privileged accounts only, add additional query filters to match those accounts. Known False Positives: If TAP is used during user onboarding or MFA registration process, newly created accounts will also trigger this detection.

name: Entra ID - User Accessing Different Tenant
description: This rule identifies when a user accesses a 3rd party resource that is outside the control of an organization. These 3rd party resources can be configured to do a number of functions such as steal sessions, credentials, information, etc from user interactions.

name: Entra ID - User With Suspicious History Modified Authentication Information
description: This rule detects potential account takeover attempts in Microsoft Entra ID by correlating a sequence of high-risk account modifications followed by authentication changes. Specifically, it identifies users who have had their account enabled, password reset, and group memberships modified, followed by changes to their Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) settings or the user performing a self-service password reset all within a 3-day window. This pattern of activity may indicate an adversary establishing persistence after compromising a privileged account, potentially leading to unauthorized access, data exfiltration, or further lateral movement within the environment.

name: Exfiltration and Tunneling Tools Execution
description: The execution of well known tools that can be used for data exfiltration and tunneling was detected.

name: Exploited C&C Connection
description: An exploited host with vulnerabilities initiated a connection to the exploit attacker, which could indicate the host being compromised and performing C&C activities. See if the exploit was successful. Check the source host, and consider blocking.
mitreTechnique: XDR Command and Control Connection Exploitation

name: External Account Login Failure Anomaly
