description: An anomalously large number of user login failures was observed for an account. Check with the user.

name: External Brute-Forced Successful User Login

name: Login to Disabled Account
description: This rule identifies when secondary factor has not been provided during a risky authentication. Adversaries may look to bypass MFA controls by removing MFA devices or resetting factors. Best practice requires every user to be enrolled in MFA to ensure authentications have that extra step of validation.

name: Long App Session Anomaly

name: M365 - Suspicious Graph API Search for Sensitive Mail
description: Detects suspicious keywords being searched in an individual mailbox through the Microsoft Graph API. This behavior is commonly observed upon initial access into a compromised mailbox. Adversaries typically search the mailbox for mail items containing sensitive documents, or interesting conversations to insert themselves into in order to subvert communications.

name: M365 Exchange Online - Audit Logging Disabled Individual Mailbox
description: Detects when audit logging is disabled on an individual mailbox. This could indicate that an adversary is attempting to hide their track by disabling monitoring of their activities.

name: M365 Exchange Online - Authentication to Mailbox from Malicious IP Address
description: Identifies successful authentication into Microsoft Exchange mailbox's from high-confidence malicious IP addresses.

name: M365 Exchange Online - Authentication to Mailbox from Malicious IP Address
description: Identifies successful authentication into Microsoft Exchange mailbox's from high-confidence malicious IP addresses.

name: M365 Exchange Online - Email Forwarding Inbox Rule
description: This detection identifies when email forwarding is enabled within an Outlook mailbox through the use of inbox rules, potentially indicating malicious exfiltration. The inbox rule may be configured to forward sensitive emails to an external or unauthorized account, posing a risk to data confidentiality and integrity. Email forwarding rules can be used by attackers to monitor the activities of a victim, steal information, and further gain intelligence on the victim or the victims organization to use as part of further exploitation.

name: M365 Exchange Online - Email Forwarding Mailbox Setting
description: This rule identifies when email forwarding is enabled within an Outlook mailbox through the mail forwarding setting. In malicious scenarios, this mailbox setting is usually configured to forward sensitive emails to an external or unauthorized account, posing a risk to data confidentiality and integrity. Email forwarding can be used by attackers to monitor the activities of a victim, steal information, and further gain intelligence on the victim or the victims organization to use as part of further exploitation.

name: M365 Exchange Online - Mail Redirect Via Transport Rule
description: This rule identifies when an Exchange Transport Rule is configured to redirect messages. Depending on the configuration the rule may apply to all messages which could have severe consequences within the organization.

name: M365 Exchange Online - Mailbox Delegation FullAccess Access Rights
description: Detects instances where AccessRights are modified on a mailbox to allow for FullAccess. Adversaries in control of administrative accounts may grant themselves the FullAccess permission to control the entirety of a mailbox of interest. This approach allows them to persistently access sensitive information, impersonate legitimate users, and maintain control over email accounts.

name: M365 Exchange Online - New or Modified Management Role Assignments
description: This rule identifies when any management role assignment is created in Microsoft Exchange. Depending on the newly assigned role, it could grant extensive access to mailboxes in the environment. These management roles are specific to Exchange and do not extend to other Microsoft products like Microsoft Entra ID. This activity is infrequent and may indicate an adversary attempting to escalate privileges to access additional mailboxes.

name: M365 Exchange Online - Persistence via Identity Provider
description: This rule identifies when potentially unauthorized domains or identity providers are created or modified as identified through Microsoft Exchange logging.

name: M365 Exchange Online - Suspicious Inbox Rule Name
description: Detects when a new inbox rule is created in a Microsoft 365 mailbox with a suspicious rule name.

name: M365 Exchange Online - Suspicious Modification of Default or Anonymous Mailbox Permissions
description: This rule detects changes to Default or Anonymous user permissions on Microsoft 365 mailboxes. Such modifications can grant extensive access, either to all authenticated users or anyone outside the tenant, potentially leading to unauthorized access or data exfiltration. Adversaries may exploit these changes to maintain access across compromised mailboxes or to discover and exploit additional mailboxes.

name: M365 Exchange Online - Suspicious Search Query On Exchange Mailbox
description: Detects suspicious keywords being searched in an Exchange mailbox.

name: M365 Exchange Online - Unified Audit Logging Disabled Globally
description: This rule identifies when the unified audit log is disabled across an entire Microsoft 365 environment. This could indicate that an adversary is attempting to hide their track via disabling monitoring of their activities.

name: M365 OneDrive - Unusual File Extension Changed on Synchronised File
description: This rule looks for instances where there has been a OneDrive file sync of a file where the file extension has changed. This rule covers both OneDrive and SharePoint, however as SharePoint is built off a OneDrive backend all events appear as "OneDrive" events. This activity can be indicative of ransomware on a host machine where the files are synchronised to a OneDrive or SharePoint repository. This will be especially useful for organizations that have external / guest users utilising collaboration infrastructure within their environment. OneDrive/SharePoint typically has a delay of 10-20m for the event pull. Additionally OneDrive/SharePoint will generate a lot of logs. Therefore the recommended scheduling is 10m looking over a 15m time window.

name: M365 SharePoint - KQL Search for Configuration Files or Scripts
description: This detection identifies attempts to use Keyword Query Language (KQL) in SharePoint to find configuration files or scripts. KQL enables rapid searching of large SharePoint sites, utilising unique "Queriable" fields such as "FileExtension". Whilst this feature is useful for legitimate purposes, attackers may exploit it to quickly locate sensitive information, developer tools, or system administration utilities that could aid in further compromise or lateral movement. The rule specifically looks for KQL searches targeting file extensions commonly associated with scripts or configuration files (.ps1, .bat) or containing keywords that might indicate sensitive information ("password", "ipconfig"). The rule looks for multiple matches indicating a long search string, for example: ((FileExtension:ps1 OR FileExtension:bat OR FileExtension:sh AND (content:"password=* OR content:"pwd" OR content:"secret")

description: The Suspicious PowerShell Script rules are used to identify suspicious activity relating to PowerShell scripts. Any one or more of these will trigger the Suspicious PowerShell Script alert types.

name: Suspicious PowerShell Script Detection
description: A suspicious powershell script was detected in your environment. Determine if this was expected or known activity.

name: Suspicious Process Creation Commandline
description: The Suspicious Process Creation Commandline rules are used to identify suspicious activity relating to command-line process creation. Any one or more of these will trigger the Suspicious Process Creation Commandline alert types.

name: Suspicious Process Creation Commandline Detection
description: An abnormal process was created via commandline in your environment.

name: Suspicious Process Following RDP Logon
description: A suspicious process was identified by a user that recently that logged into a Domain Controller via RDP.

name: Suspicious Process Spawned by SharePoint IIS Worker Process
description: Detects the creation of a suspicious child process, such as a command shell or common reconnaissance tool, by the Internet Information Services (IIS) worker process (w3wp.exe) running a SharePoint application pool. This behavior is highly anomalous and is a strong indicator of post-exploitation activity. An attacker, after successfully exploiting a remote code execution (RCE) vulnerability like CVE-2025-53770, will often spawn a shell to execute further commands on the compromised server.

name: Suspicious PsExec Execution
description: The Suspicious PsExec Execution rules detect suspicious SMB traffic related to PsExec Execution activities. Any one or more of these will trigger the Suspicious PsExec Execution alert type.

name: Suspicious Script Execution from Temp or Downloads Directory
description: Detects `wscript.exe` executions where the command line includes indicators of execution from user or temp folders involving `.zip` or `.js` files

name: Suspicious SignIns From A Non Registered Device
description: Detects risky authentication from a non AD registered device without MFA being required.

name: Suspicious User Agent Detection
description: A connection attempt utilizing an abnormal user agent was detected in your environment.

name: Suspicious Windows Active Directory Operation
description: The Suspicious Windows Active Directory Operation rules are used to identify suspicious activity with Windows Active Directory operation. Any one or more of these will trigger the Suspicious Windows Active Directory Operation alert type.

name: Suspicious Windows Logon Event
description: The Suspicious Windows Logon Event rules are used to identify suspicious activity with Windows logons. Any one or more of these will trigger the Suspicious Windows Logon alert types.

name: Suspicious Windows Network Connection
description: The Suspicious Windows Network Connection rules are used to identify suspicious Windows network connection activities. Any one or more of these will trigger the Suspicious Windows Network Connection alert type.

name: Suspicious Windows Registry Event: Impact
description: The Suspicious Windows Registry Event: Impact rules are used to identify suspicious Windows registry events usually in the impact stage. Any one or more of these will trigger the Suspicious Windows Registry Event: Impact alert type.

name: Suspicious Windows Registry Event: Persistence
description: The Suspicious Windows Registry Event: Persistence rules are used to identify suspicious Windows registry events usually in the persistence stage. Any one or more of these will trigger the Suspicious Windows Registry Event: Persistence alert type.

name: Suspicious Windows Service Installation
description: The Suspicious Windows Service Installation rules are used to identify suspicious activity with service installation. Any one or more of these will trigger the Suspicious Windows Service Installation alert type.

name: T1047 Wmiprvse Wbemcomn DLL Hijack
description: The T1047 Wmiprvse Wbemcomn DLL Hijack rules detect suspicious SMB traffic related to WMI DLL Hijack activities. Any one or more of these will trigger the T1047 Wmiprvse Wbemcomn DLL Hijack alert type.

name: Trend Micro Vision One - Detections
description: Stellar Cyber detected a suspicious alert originally reported by Trend Micro Vision One.

name: Unapproved Asset Activity
description: Activity of an asset that was marked as unapproved in one of the Investigate | Asset Analytics tabs has been observed.

name: Uncommon Application Anomaly
description: Private (internal assets) to public (Internet) traffic has revealed an application that has never been seen before (or been seen very rarely). Investigate that application and ensure that it is benign.

name: Uncommon Process Anomaly
description: Private (internal assets) to public (Internet) traffic has revealed an application that has never been seen before (or been seen very rarely). Investigate that application and ensure that it is benign.

name: User Access Blocked by Azure Conditional Access
description: Detect access has been blocked by Conditional Access policies. The access policy does not allow token issuance which might be sights≈ of unauthorizeed login to valid accounts.

name: User Added to Security Enabled Local Group Following Password Reset
description: A user was added to a Security-Enabled Local Group following a password reset, this could indicate potential privelege escalation or staging for lateral movement.

name: User Asset Access Anomaly
description: A user who typically uses a small, consistent number of assets was observed in Windows logons, Kerberos service tickets, or SMB traffic to access a new asset. Investigate the asset and user to see if this was expected.

name: User Login Location Anomaly
description: A login to a user account occurred from a source IP address that is anomalously distant from the nearest location typically observed for logins to that user account.

name: User Process Usage Anomaly
description: A user who typically executes a small, consistent number of processes suddenly executed a new process. Investigate the process to see if it is benign. Check with the user to see if this process was expected.

name: Varonis DatAdvantage - Detections
description: Stellar Cyber detected a suspicious alert originally reported by Varonis DatAdvantage.

name: Volume Shadow Copy Deletion via VssAdmin
description: The vssadmin.exe utility was used to delete the Shadow Copy on an endpoint. Ransomware and other malware do this to prevent system recovery. Check with the user.

name: Volume Shadow Copy Deletion via WMIC
description: The wmic.exe utility was used to delete the Shadow Copy on an endpoint. Ransomware and other malware do this to prevent system recovery. Check with the user.

name: WAF Internal Attacker Anomaly
description: Internal web requests from a private IP address have been blocked/alerted by the Web Application Firewall (WAF). Investigate the source requester and ensure they are not compromised.

name: WAF Rule Violation Anomaly
description: Web requests have been blocked/alerted by the Web Application Firewall (WAF) due to a surge in violations or violating a rule that is rarely invoked. Investigate the blocked/alerted web requests and ensure they are benign.

name: Web Shell File Detected in LAYOUTS Directory
description: Detects the creation or modification of a suspicious aspx file, within the critical SharePoint LAYOUTS directory. This activity is a definitive indicator of a web shell being planted on the server. The LAYOUTS directory is a common target for attackers because files placed there can be executed by the web server. The file spinstall0.aspx is a known indicator of compromise associated with post-exploitation activity following a successful SharePoint vulnerability exploit.

name: Windows Account Lockout Event
description: A windows user's account was locked out in your environment.

name: Windows Audit Log Cleared
description: The windows audit log was cleared by a user in your environment.

name: Windows Domain Policy Changed
description: A change was detected for a local computer's security policy.

name: Windows Network Access Suspicious desktop.ini Action
description: The Windows Network Access Suspicious desktop.ini Action rules detect suspicious SMB traffic accessing desktop.ini files. Any one or more of these will trigger the Windows Network Access Suspicious desktop.ini Action alert type.

name: Windows Security-Enabled Global Group Created
description: A security-enabled global group was created.

name: Windows Security-Enabled Local Group Created
description: A security-enabled local group was created.

name: Windows Security-Enabled Universal Group Created
description: A security-enabled universal group was created.

name: Windows Suspicious Process Creation
description: The Suspicious Windows Process Creation rules are used to identify suspicious activity associated with process creation. Any one or more of these will trigger the Suspicious Process Creation alert type.

name: Windows User Added to Security-Enabled Global Domain Admins Group
description: A member was added to a security-enabled global Domain Adminsgroup.

name: Windows User Added to Security-Enabled Local Administrators Group
description: A member was added to a security-enabled local group.

name: Windows User Added to Universal Group - Enterprise Admins
description: A member was added to the security-enabled universal group Enterprise Admins.

name: Windows User Added to Universal Group - Schema Admins
description: A member was added to the security-enabled universal group Schema Admins.

name: Windows User Removed from Domain Admins Group
description: A member was removed from a security-enabled global Domain Admins group.

name: Windows User Removed from Local Administrators Group
description: A member was removed from a security-enabled local administrators group.

name: WindowsDefenderAntivirus
description: Stellar Cyber detected a suspicious alert originally reported by Windows Defender Antivirus.

name: WMI Backdoor Exchange Transport Agent
description: A WMI backdoor in Exchange Transport Agents via WMI event filters was detected.

name: WMI Firewall Rule Enabled via Netsh
description: Detects the use of netsh to enable Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) firewall rules, which may be used for remote execution or lateral movement

name: Zip A Folder With PowerShell For Staging In Temp
description: Detects the use of living off the land tools to zip a file and stage it in the Windows temporary folder for later exfiltration
